Quality of time There are two types of time for our mental activity: high quality time and low quality time.

  • High-quality time is when we have all the resources at our disposal at once, e.g .: materials, free hands, ears, eyes possibility of 100% focus, silence space, teacher etc. Then we should have conversations and solve doubts with the teacher, write essays.
  • Low-quality time, on the other hand, is when our resources are limited or we don't have enough time to start a more complex task: we can listen and speak but we cannot look (e.g. driving a car or walking down the street), we can listen and look, but we cannot speak (e.g. in the subway or tram), we can look and operate manually, but not hear (e.g. in an old, noisy train), etc. QUEST: You will gain a lot of time by eliminating time eaters - usually low quality time. Plan how you will use it and be sure to write a study plan for the next week.

draft_attributes.serialized_body: There are several factors responsible for success in learning, e.g. language talent, age, method and time. We have no influence on talent or time, but we can choose the method appropriately and maximize the time spent on learning. Even the best method will not work if we do not devote enough time to it ("something multiplied by 0 is 0"). TASK: Think about how you like to learn. in the morning, during the day, in the evening or at night? with a textbook or in the form of an electronic course? individually or in a group? face to face with a teacher or via the Internet? How to learn Regardless of your answers above, the brain always learns according to the principles below. Use them, and learning and remembering will finally be effective. Build personal associations while learning new content (vocabulary or grammar). Combine each new phrase with an experience that is already behind you. For example, answer the following questions: "When was the last time I had contact with ... (insert a foreign word)" ?, "What is the meaning of ... (insert a foreign word) in my life"? When you learn a phrase, immediately try to recall it from memory. Just don't be influenced by the fact that you just read it. Recalling from memory immediately gives you much better results in remembering content than "studying" a given content for a long time without effort to recall it. Don't study too much - sounds interesting? It only makes no sense to seem to learn more than the brain needs to remember content. If you remember an item from memory when recalling it, move on. Use repetition methods. Thanks to this, you will only repeat phrases and rules that are close to being forgotten. You will save time and not over-train your brain by repeating only what actually requires it. With each repetition, strengthen associations and add new information. When you repeat a given linguistic element anew, you "rewrite" its meaning in your life.

draft_attributes.serialized_body: Eliminate the bad factors Even if you follow all the learning and remembering techniques from Step Three, they will be useless if you don't eliminate bad habits. Find out what can significantly damage your efforts. You learn or repeat in a hostile environment, in uncomfortable stressful conditions, such as noise or clutter - especially if you are a visual learner. When you learn, you lack concentration. You don't focus on content and learning, your mind drifts away. You read / repeat the same things over and over again, but you don't remember them, but you have the illusion that you are learning a lot. You are repeating the material under different conditions than when the material was originally memorized. Remembering and recalling information should take place under the same circumstances to optimize lasting memory. You sleep too little or badly - the brain has no chance to get rid of toxins or properly carry out the process of analyzing and consolidating information, i.e. learning, during sleep. You live under stress - Your brain focuses its energy and resources on dealing with stressful factors, learning takes a back seat. You barely move - the brain requires our body to be in motion (like in cave times). Then it functions optimally. You don't exercise, the brain rebels: why learn and remember? You have a bad diet - Your brain is not getting the nutrients it needs.

You learn or repeat in a hostile environment, in uncomfortable stressful conditions, such as noise or clutter - especially if you are a visual learner.
When you learn, you lack concentration. You don't focus on content and learning, your mind drifts away. You read / repeat the same things over and over again, but you don't remember them, but you have the illusion that you are learning a lot.
You are repeating the material under different conditions than when the material was originally memorized. Remembering and recalling information should take place under the same circumstances to optimize lasting memory.
You sleep too little or badly - the brain has no chance to get rid of toxins or properly carry out the process of analyzing and consolidating information, i.e. learning, during sleep.
You live under stress - Your brain focuses its energy and resources on dealing with stressful factors, learning takes a back seat.
You barely move - the brain requires our body to be in motion (like in cave times). Then it functions optimally. You don't exercise, the brain rebels: why learn and remember?
You have a bad diet - Your brain is not getting the nutrients it needs.
